description: High-level overview of Canadian contract law principles. Covers formation, interpretation, breach, damages, and common defences. Educational framework only â€” not legal advice.

topics.title: Formation: Offer and Acceptance
topics.coreDefinition: A legally binding contract requires a clear offer, an unequivocal acceptance, consideration, and intention to create legal relations.
frameworkSteps: Identify a clear offer with definite terms.
Confirm acceptance that mirrors the offer (no material variation).
Verify consideration (something of value exchanged).
Assess intention to create legal relations.
quickExamples: A signed service agreement outlining scope and payment.
An email confirming acceptance of quoted terms.
commonMistakes: Confusing negotiations with a final offer.
Assuming informal discussions automatically create binding agreements.

topics.title: Consideration
topics.coreDefinition: Consideration requires that each party provide something of value. Past consideration generally does not qualify.
frameworkSteps: Identify what each party is promising or providing.
Determine whether exchange is legally sufficient.
Assess whether modification requires fresh consideration.
quickExamples: Promise to deliver goods in exchange for payment.
commonMistakes: Assuming moral obligation equals legal consideration.
Believing contract modifications are valid without new consideration.

topics.title: Intention and Capacity
topics.coreDefinition: Parties must intend legal consequences and possess legal capacity to contract.
frameworkSteps: Assess whether context implies legal intent (commercial vs social setting).
Confirm parties have legal capacity (age, mental competence).
Evaluate whether any incapacity renders agreement voidable.
quickExamples: Contracts with minors may be unenforceable in some contexts.
commonMistakes: Assuming all written agreements are automatically enforceable.

topics.title: Contract Interpretation
topics.coreDefinition: Contracts are interpreted contextually, giving words their ordinary meaning within the entire agreement and surrounding circumstances.
frameworkSteps: Read entire contract as a whole.
Consider factual matrix (background context).
Resolve ambiguities using standard interpretive principles.
quickExamples: Ambiguous clause interpreted against drafter (contra proferentem).
commonMistakes: Isolating one clause without reading entire agreement.
Ignoring context at time of formation.

topics.title: Breach of Contract
topics.coreDefinition: A breach occurs when a party fails to perform contractual obligations without lawful excuse.
frameworkSteps: Identify contractual obligation.
Determine whether performance failed or was deficient.
Assess materiality of breach.
Consider available remedies.
quickExamples: Failure to deliver goods on agreed date.
commonMistakes: Assuming minor deviation automatically voids contract.

topics.title: Damages and Remedies
topics.coreDefinition: Damages aim to place the injured party in the position they would have been in had the contract been performed.
frameworkSteps: Assess direct losses.
Evaluate foreseeability (Hadley principle).
Consider mitigation obligations.
Review contractual limitation clauses.
quickExamples: Lost profits reasonably foreseeable at time of contract.
Duty to mitigate loss by seeking substitute contract.

topics.title: Common Contract Defences
topics.coreDefinition: Certain circumstances may render contracts void, voidable, or unenforceable.
frameworkSteps: Identify alleged defect (misrepresentation, mistake, duress, undue influence).
Determine whether defence voids or makes contract voidable.
Assess evidence supporting defence.
commonMistakes: Confusing unfair bargain with legal duress.
Assuming verbal misstatements automatically void agreement.
